PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Network Pictures as a Research Device in Business Networks
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
This project was developed for my PhD. For the past twenty years, drawing on the Industrial Network Approach, Industrial Marketing and Purchasing Group researchers have been trying to get a better understanding of organisational networks related issues. Researchers frequently highlight that whatever the researched phenomena, it is important to consider actors? subjective views of the world. The concept of Network Pictures as introduced in the IMP (Industrial Marketing and Purchasing) body of literature by Ford et al. (2002), refers to those subjective views and despite its recognised importance no in-depth research had been conducted so far on the concept which has thus remained blurred. Ford et al. (2002) brought in this concept to emphasise that the network is in fact a varying thing depending on what people see. The question is whether this can be translated into a research device, so that researchers may see in a structured and analytical way what an actor?s picture is. This is what this research project is about. 
The concept?s theoretical foundations are uncovered by reviewing some principles from Sense-Making Theory. This review results most importantly in the identification of a close association between actors? views of the world and the outcome of those actors? sense making processes or frameworks. The relevance of actors? views to obtain a clearer understanding of organisational networks is highlighted when the relation that is believed to exist between those views and action in organisational networks is addressed. 
With the aim of developing Network Pictures as research tool a two-stage method is put forward and carried out. The method consisted of operationalising the construct of Network Pictures and then testing it in two different network contexts to see if it was usable and useful for carrying out research in organisational networks. The results point to the usability and usefulness of the developed device: not only does it allow for capturing what is believed to be individuals? views of the world in a rich and comprehensive way, as it also shows diversity between individuals in different contexts. Also and interestingly, some of the identified ?practitioner theories? were found to be not coherent with some IMP theoretical cornerstones.
This project was developed with my PhD dissertation.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Network Pictures as a Research Device in Business Networks

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Network Dynamics in University Science Parks and Incubators: A Comparative Analysis of Business and Social Processes Intro
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
While technological aspects of university incubators and university science parks (USPs) have received considerable attention, the business processes which characterise such entities have not been analysed to the same detail. This includes business and social processes between different levels of actors: the incubator/USP itself, the companies within the incubator/USP, the entrepreneur at the core of these companies, and these companies and entrepreneurs ?outside? connections. An understanding of such processes can be used to optimise USP management as well as entrepreneurial company management decisions.
Our research project is aimed at understanding the multi-level business and social processes characterising the network structures of university incubators and USPs. We look in-depth into the business network configurations within the incubator, i.e. mapping what is taking place at the incubator (e.g. are there any central/peripheral/gatekeeper companies, are there any clusters of companies within the incubator, do companies interact mostly with companies within or outside the incubator, is interaction taking place mostly between companies with the same nature, etc.). With regard to social and business processes, a special focus will be on understanding issues of dynamics in the network, i.e. how do actors cope with change. 
The project involves researchers from Manchester Business School (MBS), namely from the mIMP Group (www.mbs.ac.uk/research/marketingpurchasing/index.aspx, a b2b marketing research group), as well as from the Faculty of Economics of Porto - FEP, in Portugal. Moreover, groups of MSc students in Portugal (3 students) and the UK (5 students) will analyse different USPs. The work will be coordinated by Professor Peter Naudй, Professor Stephan Henneberg and Dr Carla Ramos at MBS, and by Dr Catarina Roseira at FEP.
Data will be collected from the USP associated with the University of Porto - UPTEC, and from the one related to the University of Manchester ? UMIC (namely from the North Campus Incubator, as well as the One Central Park). This will allow for a comparative case study analysis of USPs in a converging country (i.e. Portugal, characterised by an infrastructure of a developed country but exhibiting low innovation performance) vis-а-vis a traditional developed country with high innovation performance (i.e. the UK). One manager from each company, will be asked to fill in an on-line questionnaire (that will take around 15 minutes to fill in) and to participate in an informal interview (length of approximately 20 minutes). The incubator management/university will also be included.
The research project will allow for a better understanding of the processes that are taking place within the incubator, especially regarding how different actors cope with change. This will allow all parties involved to find new ways of engaging with other companies and with the incubator management, and therefore help optimise the performance of entrepreneurial companies as well as the overall incubator/USP.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: The Emergence of Innovation Networks: The Cases of the Health Cluster Portugal and Galp Energia
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
The idea that firms need to adopt a network approach to innovation has been widely recognized in the managerial as well as academic spheres (Biemans 1995; Dilk et al. 2008). Moreover, private and public organisations are increasingly working together in innovation projects (Etzkowitz & Leydesdorff 2000). Nevertheless, there is still a lot of debate on what activities and especially network configurations serve best the final aim of increasing firms? and countries? innovativeness and competitiveness (Gemunden et al. 1996; Perks et al. 2006). Specific discussions include diverse aspects of innovation networks, namely their creation, configuration, underlying innovation processes, resulting innovation outcomes, and the role played by a focal/enabling actor.   This research project aims at analysing these specific aspects of innovation networks. We expect to provide valuable insights that can help firms and other organizations to decide how to manage or support different innovation networks, and guide public policy makers in framing successful innovation networks. The aim of this project is thus to enhance the extant knowledge on these interconnected areas, focusing on how the developing form of an IN (i.e. emergent or triggered) and resulting business relationships affect the network configuration dynamics, the innovation processes and ultimately innovation outcomes.  
The research is conducted with the Health Cluster Portugal, a national cluster of organizations aimed at fostering the creation of a national competitive and technological cluster that draws on the extant competences and potential of the medical sector in Portugal; promoting the economic and social development of the involved regions, as well as of Portugal as a whole; increasing exports; and finally, contributing to the improvement of the health care system and services. Our case therefore constitutes a services network aimed at ?improving Well-Being through Transformative Service? (Ostrom et al., 2010, p. 6). Services focusing on the improvement of wellbeing constitute a research priority that requires further investigation (Ostrom et al., 2010).
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: The Emergence of Innovation Networks: The Cases of the Health Cluster Portugal and Galp Energia

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Service Innovation & Infusion: Processes and Outcomes
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
In light of the highly competitive nature of industrial markets, researchers recently have focused on product-related services as a means to achieve successful differentiation and thereby advantages over competition. While the service dominant logic (Vargo and Lusch 2004) promotes rigorous rethinking towards a service orientation emphasizing value-in-use, so-called product service strategies aim at expanding the product offering of a firm by providing additional services around a core product offering. According to Frambach et al. (1997, p.341), such product services are defined as ?the set of all potential additional services a supplier can supplement his product offering with, in order to differentiate his offering relative to the competitors? as perceived by (potential) customers and distributors.? However, while many manufacturing firms traditionally provide services to their customers in terms of delivery, installation, maintenance or training, those services have become industry standards and do not necessarily provide many opportunities for differentiation (Mathieu 2001). Therefore, it has been suggested that manufacturing firms develop additional service offerings beyond these complementary services in order to achieve advantages over competition (Mathieu 2001). Service innovation in this context could be either targeted at establishing additional services as means to build additional revenue streams, or as an instrument to strengthen business relationships via relationship specific investments (Frambach et al. 1997). The differentiation between product services focusing on economic and relational outcomes is crucial in order to understand how product services innovations can help enhancing the competitive position of a firm. Therefore, it is the aim of this project to develop such an understanding and investigate the interrelationships between different types of product services, specifically regarding the underlying processes to deliver such product services, and the outcomes of such product services. In particular, it is expected that services targeted at strengthening the business relationship mediate the effect of the more economic-oriented services on organizational performance. In this context the role of service innovation and a firm?s service orientation is central to the process of developing successful service strategies (Gebauer et al. 2010). Since research in this area is very rare and limited, an initial qualitative and comparative case study is proposed as a first step to develop an understanding of how manufacturing firms utilize product services for both relationship enhancing and revenue generating purposes. In this effort, research collaborations were already established with two large manufacturing companies in Germany (e.g. Jungheinrich, the second largest manufacturer of forklift trucks) to conduct in-depth qualitative studies with multiple interviews, including not just the perspectives of the focal firm but also those of key customers and suppliers. 
This proposed contributes to the existing literature in business marketing and business strategy in various ways. First, it develops a conceptual model that links product services to both organizational performance and key relationship attributes. Further, the study provides insights into key issues related to service innovation in an industrial market context, both from a process and an outcome perspective. For this purpose, multiple stakeholders are incorporated. Second, the study establishes the basis for an operationalisation of product service strategies by developing measurement instruments that can be applied in future research. Finally, the proposed research provides the basis for future large scale quantitative studies that can be used to confirm and generalize the findings from the two case studies.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Networking Capability, Networking Rent, and Firm Performance
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
The aim of this project was to develop and empirically test a conceptual model of networking capability in inter-organisational business networks. Specific attention is given to capabilities relating to three business relationship stages: relationship initiation, relationship development, and relationship termination. While studies have shown that business relationships develop over time (Jap and Anderson 2007), research is very limited with respect to how organisations manage their business relationships across relationship stages, and how these networking activities link to organizational performance. Prior research has conceptualized and operationalised concepts related to network management activities, such as network competences/capabilities (Ritter, Wilkinson et al. 2002; Walter, Auer et al. 2006). However, existing studies have not captured how these competences correspond with the evolving nature of business relationships and networks. 
Networks evolve in many ways and how well an organisation anticipates and responds to changes is vital for its survival. Network change can be related, for example, to new firms joining or other firms leaving an organization?s business network (Gadde and Mattson, 1987). Also, the characteristics of networks can change in terms of power, dynamics, broadness, and indirectness of the network (Corsaro et al. 2010). The network as a whole can also be affected by any shifts in the atmosphere or dynamics of specific relationships. Business networks can thus be labelled as dynamic structures (Anderson et al., 1994; Easton and Araujo, 1994; Halinen and Tornross, 2010), and anticipating and responding to network changes is crucial for firms given that it allows them to identify and pursue new opportunities as well as prevent possible negative effects. In these situations firms rely on their capabilities to evaluate which of the relationships are essential and provide future opportunities, which of them are taking up too many resources compared to the benefits they provide to the firm, and which relationships are or have the potential of harming the organisation. Our focal construct of networking capability refers to firms? ability to assess their network environment and the corresponding actions to respond by strategically initiating, developing and terminating certain business relationships.
A model of the different relational outcomes of distinct aspects of networking capabilities is developed and tested empirically, including several moderation hypotheses. For this purpose, we carried a UK-based empirical cross-industry survey carried out via a marketing research company (around 250 datapoints to enable multi-group SEM analysis, each datapoint consists of two respondents from middle/higher management to reduce common method variance). The study contributes to the existing literature in business marketing and business strategy in various ways. First, it provides a conceptual model of networking capability that addresses all relevant stages of business relationships. Second, the study operationalises networking capability by developing partly new measurement scales that can be applied in future research. Finally, the authors test how networking capabilities affect organizational innovativeness and eventually firm performance.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Cognition in Business Networks - Understanding Network Pictures Complexity
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
This research project corresponds to my first Post-doc, that took place over a six months period at Manchester Business School (MBS).
Companies are embedded in complex networks of interconnected relationships, with most research on industrial systems being based on this dictum (Hеkansson and Johanson, 1992; Hеkansson and Snehota, 1989). Within these relationships, it is through networking that a company can access the resources that are required to develop and sustain business activity (Pfeffer & Salancik, 1978). Networking is defined as all interactions of an actor in a business network, comprising all activities concerning the management of the existing relationships, the management of the position occupied in the surrounding network and the strategies of how to network (Ford et al., 2002 ).
Such activities within the network are grounded on the underlying beliefs about the network by relevant actors. Based on principles of organizational cognitive science, organizational actor's actions can be understood as being conditioned by their perceptions of the world around them (Weick, 1979). In business networks, this can be translated into how actors' cognitive schemata, i.e. their views of their surroundings, condition their networking activities, either by restricting or expanding their available options (Anderson et al., 1994, Ford et al., 2002). Recently, there has been growing interest in this relationship between actors' perceptions of their surroundings and their networking activities (Corsaro et al., 2011; Ramos, 2008 ). Specifically, the concept of network pictures was developed to capture an organizational actor's beliefs about his/her network (Colville and Pye, 2010, Mouzas et al., 2008).
Our article contributes to understanding aspects of sense-making in business networks, especially network pictures. Specifically, we focus on understanding one characteristic of network pictures (or an actor's cognitive schemata) that has been shown to influence networking activities (or decision making) and consequently firms' performance (see e.g., McNamara et al., 2002 and Walsh, 1995): their underlying complexity. The aim is to develop a multi-dimensional construct of complexity that can be used to assess the cognitive conditions of actors' views regarding their surrounding network. Additionally, the research project seeks to explore the relationship between certain contextual factors and network picture complexity. This is done by applying the developed multi-dimensional complexity construct to the network pictures of forty-seven managers, in seventeen companies from two distinct networks. Degrees of network picture complexity are subsequently associated with different independent factors, for example managers' personal characteristics, and their company's characteristics. This analysis allows us to contribute to the literature on sense-making in business networks, which can then be used to further understand networking activities in business relationships ( Brown et al., 2008). Therefore, although the core purpose of this research does not rely on investigating the relationship that is believed to exist between network pictures and networking, future investigation on this relationship can be anchored in this piece of research. The findings show that complexity is higher for individuals with more experience in externally-oriented functions than in internally-oriented ones, and that the more complex companies' internal structures are, the more complex are the individuals' network pictures. The data analysis also indicates that there is an inverted-U shaped relationship between network picture complexity and the number of years a company has been established in a business. Finally, and unexpectedly, we find a U-shaped relationship between network picture complexity and the number of years of an individual's working experience.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Cognition in Business Networks - Understanding Network Pictures Complexity

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Cognition and Action in Business Networks
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
This research project corresponds to my second Post-doc, that took place over a 2,5 years period at the Faculty of Economics of the University of Porto, and at Manchester Business School (MBS).
The study of managerial cognition, and especially the concept of network pictures (Ramos and Ford, 2010), has been a specific focus of recent research in the area of business networks (Purchase et al. 2010). Different theoretical frameworks have been combined (Geiger and Finch, 2009, Kragh and Andersen, 2009) to provide explanations of business phenomena regarding managerial decisions in complex networks and to understand the process of network positioning and organizing in business networks. In this project we utilize the concept of network pictures, i.e. referring to business actors' subjective mental representations (or frameworks) of their surroundings, and thus as sense-making tools that underlie decision-making in networks (Ford et al., 2003). In recent years, various contributions relating to the construct of network pictures have emerged in the IMP Group's business marketing literature, e.g. dimensional conceptualizations (Henneberg et al., 2006) and operationalizations (Ramos & Ford, 2010). However, while these recent conceptual and empirical studies relating to network pictures are evidence of scholarly interest in the topic, the current treatment of the concept remains decoupled from strategic decisions about network position. It has been suggested that network pictures are significant in the process of organizing in business networks as they generate economic consequences for actors via shaping activities. Such strategic actions in networks are described by Ford et al. (2003) as ?networking? activities. Specifically, the extant literature has not provided details or empirical evidence about the relationship between actors' network pictures and actors' networking strategies within business networks. We focus in our research project on the uni-directional impact of managerial cognition on managerial action while being cognizant of the fact that there exist feedback loops in terms of strategic actions affecting managerial cognition (Ford et al., 2003). Our idea is in fact to start from a simple research design and add step by step further complexity to it.
In the strategy and organizational psychology literature, the link between managerial cognition and managerial behavior is clearly recognized as being important (Goodhew et al., 2005), while it is also accepted that it needs further development (Schneider & Angelmar, 1993). Currently, no such understanding exists regarding the specifics of network-related cognition and networking strategies in the IMP field of research. Given this gap in the literature, the objective of this project is to empirically investigate how aspects of actors' network pictures affect, condition and frame strategic managerial decisions, specifically networking.
For this purpose, we employ insights from cognitive sense-making theory (Weick, 1995), strategy literature (Hodgkinson et al., 2002; Hoffmann, 2007), and the industrial network approach (Ford et al., 2003), to devise an experimental design. We utilize a pre-test to generate and assess different stimuli related to network pictures, as well as strategic networking choices. Based on this, an experiment with 445 experienced managers across industries was undertaken. The results improve our understanding of the role that actors' network pictures play in shaping managerial decisions, they enable us to provide an understanding of how different aspects of managerial sense-making affect strategic action in business networks. Furthermore, they provide an operationalization of both network pictures and networking activity concepts. This project also provides a methodological contribution, by applying an experimental design to the study of business networks.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Environmental Drivers and Supply Chain Sustainability Performance
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
Over the last two decades, organisations have experienced a growing pressure to take action on the resource and environmental consequences of their products and production processes (Kleindorfer et al., 2005). Adoption of sustainability practices however, needs coordinated efforts across the supply chain (Pullman et al., 2009). In fact, consumers hold firms responsible for sustainability practices across all of their supply chain members, both upstream and downstream. 
Traditionally, researchers have focused primarily on the environmental issues in supply chains (Pullman et al., 2009) but later, social aspects of sustainability received more attention. Recent focus has shifted to incorporate both environmental and social issues (also known as corporate social responsibility) together into a single scale (Waddock and Graves, 1997). Furthermore, two industries have seen more attention from sustainability researchers in the past. These industries include the transportation industry, due to its large carbon footprint and environmental impacts, and the consumer product industry, due to being the closest to the consumer end of the supply chain (Carter and Easton, 2011). This is while many other industries have not been examined in terms of their sustainability activities. Athough a number of empirical studies have examined the relationships between specific sustainability issues and performance outcomes, most of them neglect to link the adoption of environmental practices to economic, social and operational performance. Thus, an expanded view of environmental practices and the resulting economic, social and operational performance outcomes are important topics for research as there has been a lack of attention in this area. 
In particular, what makes economic and operational performance outcomes more important is that firms are more likely to follow green supply chain practices if they realise that these practices actually lead into financial and operational benefits (Bowen et al., 2001). Hence, as suggested by Rao and Holt (2005), there is a clear need for research that establishes the potential link between improved economic and operational performance and green supply chain initiatives. If these relationships become apparent to practitioners, they would be encouraged to drive their supply and demand chains greener than before as they would seem a worthwhile investment.
Logically, environmental drivers of sustainability should impact the environmental sustainability performance of firms. However, what is more interesting is to find out whether these environmental drivers also have an impact on social and economic sustainability performance of firms. To the best of our knowledge, this area has not been explored before. Therefore, this research project aims at filling this gap in the literature by addressing the following research questions: How do environmental sustainability practices in supply chain impact not only the environmental sustainability performance outcome, but also the social and economic sustainability performance outcomes? How is operational performance impacted by sustainability performance outcomes? To what extent size of the firm changes the strength of the impact of environmental drivers on sustainability performance and operational performance? The research project entails a purely quantitative approach, with data being collected in the UK via survey.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Value Constellations and Innovation Networks: the Case of Science and Technology Parks
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
Research in marketing has seen a growing focus on business relationships rather than only on market transactions, specifically in the area of business marketing (Anderson, 1995). This shift in focus has been accompanied by a growing interest among researchers about the concept of ?value of business relationships? and ?value in business networks?. The recent emphasis on concepts of value-in-use and value co-creation in the emerging Service-Dominant Logic (Vargo and Lusch 2004; 2008) has put the concept of value again at centre of marketing theory. Within business marketing, the concept of value has been developed by different authors using manifold perspectives, namely customer value (Sinha and DeSarbo, 1998), supplier value (Baxter and Matear, 2004), relationship value for the customer (Ulaga and Eggert, 2006), relationship value for supplier (Mцller, Tцrrцnen, 2003), or value of the relations (Henneberg et al. 2009). Research has also introduced the time dimension and its effect on value (Eggert et al. 2005; Beverland and Lockshin, 2003). However, these studies are characterised by a tendency to focus on value generated within the dyad (i.e. the direct relationship between two business partners), therefore neglecting the impact of other relationships (e.g. indirect ones) in business network. Few scholars have developed concepts of value in a network setting, some with reference to value conceptualization and measurement (Gummesson, 2004,), and other to the value creation processes (Cova and Salle, 2008; Payne et al., 2008).
It is evident that the network setting matters for value creation, especially in business markets where the cost and benefit consequences arising from each single relationship are magnified for the involvement and interactions with other business actors. Circumstances external to a focal dyadic relationship therefore represent critical factors impacting on relationship performance and value; these could include the level of interconnectedness among network entities, the number and strength of inter-firm ties, or the interaction among different relational performance drivers (Van Den Bulte and Wuyts, 2007; Palmatier, 2008). 
Notwithstanding the growing body of literature on value as well as on business networks, our point of departure relates to the lack of conceptualisations and case examples of the issue of value in networks. In particular, our study will address the lack of studies that explore the relationship between different possible network configurations (i.e. constellations of business relationships) and the processes of value creation. We are therefore addressing the following research question: what type of network configurations are formed in innovation networks? how do network configurations affect the processes of value creation in business networks? Specifically, we report findings from a study of more than 50 high-technology entrepreneurial firms which are co-located in an innovation cluster (Daresbury Science and Innovation Centre, UK). Our different case studies include qualitative data (in-depth interviews and cognitive mapping eliciting techniques) from key informants in these firms, as well as their customers, suppliers or partner institutions, plus the Daresbury management team). We identify three different network constellations which characterise the specific relationship constellations of the entrepreneurial firms. These are related to different value dimensions for the entrepreneurial firms, its partners, as well as the innovation cluster itself. Specifically, the study identifies patterns of value creation processes, which are related to the emerging network configurations in the initial phase of entrepreneurial innovation activities.Given the unexplored nature of the topic, the implications arising from the study are relevant for theory, managerial practice, and policy decisions.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Intra-firm Sales Force Network Dynamics: A Longitudinal View
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
Sales are recognized as a strategic function that creates and delivers value for firms (Geiger and Guenzi, 2009; Ingram, 2004). Improving sales force productivity and overall performance is therefore crucial, and gradually more challenging as customers become more demanding and diversified (Avlonitis et al., 2010; Ingram, 2004). Sales literature has yet relevant areas that need further attention from academics (Evans et al., 2012). Intra-organizational aspects of the sales force are recognized as under-researched (Geiger and Guenzi, 2009). A growing body of literature has recently been exploring these issues (e.g. Evans et al., 2012), and there is a call for further empirical studies and specific investigations to address practitioners? concern with sales force productivity and performance (Geiger and Guenzi, 2009; Williams and Plouffe, 2007). Intra-organizational studies in the sales area draw on social network theory (Granoveter, 1983; Scott, 2000), and on the idea that sales people can use their own firm?s resources (e.g. intra-sales force or inter-departments) to enhance improve their social capital (Burt, 2000) and performance (Gonzalez et al., 2014; Plouffe and Barclay, 2007; Ьstьner and Iacobucci, 2012). In fact, salespeople need information about the market and customers? unique requirements to meet customer demands and create customer value (Palmatier, 2008; Slater and Narver, 2000), and a great part of that information is held internally in CRM systems or by other firm members (Plouffe and Barclay, 2007). The literature indicates that acquiring and using that internally held information to develop appropriate customer solutions has a positive impact over individual and firm?s innovativeness and performance (Lane at al., 2001; Szymanski, 1988). Intra-organizational social networks are thus the vehicle for information and knowledge transfer between individuals, groups or departments within the firm (Borgatti and Foster, 2003; Gay and Dousset, 2005; Palmatier, 2008), pointing to the ?importance of the internal relationship-building skills for successful salespeople? (Steward et al., 2010, p. 561). The structural and relational characteristics of intra-organizational social networks have been found to condition the effectiveness of that transfer of intangible assets (e.g. Borgatti and Cross, 2003; Gonzalez et al., 2014; Levin and Cross, 2004). 
The aim of this project is to contribute to the growing body of research on intra-organizational studies of sales management, investigating how the patterns of (friendship and work related) interaction amongst sales people in their local networks may be expected to evolve over time (i.e. how individual sales people behave over time in their interaction with their neighbors). To the best of our knowledge, no previous study has investigated this dynamic aspect of sales. Moreover, we also analyze if and what specific patterns of network dynamics impact on sales performance. The analysis focuses on the structural and relational aspects of network evolution. This aim is to shows the importance of understanding the existing and expected networks of relationships between members of a sales force as a means to increase the effectiveness of access to information by salespeople and within the sales force that leads to improved sales performance. We argue that the managers of the sales force, as well as top management levels, can to a certain extent put into place mechanisms that manage the existing logic of interaction to improve the effectiveness and performance. We claim that the key mechanism put in to place by individual sales people is that of closing relational triads. This discussion has practical implications for managers who are provided with some insights on how to enhance the sharing of best practices within their sales force.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Navigating Through Turbulent Business Environments: Strategies and Capabilities of Dynamic Supplier Portfolio Management
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
In the current era of turbulence, the efficiency principles upon which supply chain management (SCM) theory was developed are no longer valid. Therefore, implementing various partner development programs within relatively stable supplier portfolios is not sufficient to continuously deliver superior value (e.g. achieving successful innovation) in volatile business environments. Thus, the agility (i.e., the capacity to adapt and react in a speedy way to market changes, disruptions and opportunities) is recognized as an important feature of competitive supply portfolio management. Reconfiguring the supplier portfolio by, for example, outsourcing, initiating relationships with new suppliers or ending relationships with existing ones, may be required to address frequent external changes such as new customer demands or changes in technology. We therefore adopt a dynamic capability view of the firm and argue that to remain competitive firms need the ability to dynamically manage their supplier relationship portfolios. In other words firms need to be able to restructure, reconfigure and realign their suppliers in response to external changes that present threats or opportunities to their business. Firms are thus expected to develop a triple-A supply chain (SC), i.e., an agile, adaptable and aligned SC. Flexibility and resilience are other important characteristics for effective supply chain management (SCM) discussed in the literature, and thus we extend the Triple-A SC concept to include these features. However, for such capabilities to be effective they need to be put into action within the context of an appropriate strategy. Specifically, we distinguish between two important supplier portfolio management strategies: exploitation and exploration and evaluate under which circumstances one is preferable over the other as well as explore potential optimal levels of ambidexterity. In other words, dynamic supplier portfolio management capabilities and strategies need to be aligned for effective navigation through turbulent business environments. This is particularly important for emerging economies such as Brazil, characterized by high volatility, uncertainty, and risks. To address these issues, and thus to understand how in practical terms a firm can develop a Triple-A SC and effective SCM, a nomological model, integrating dynamic supplier relationship management capabilities and different strategy types will be developed. A quantitative model is employed to test this model, using data from a panel of supply chain managers in 250 Brazilian companies from different industries. This study thereby builds on previous work by the applicants and contributes to the literature in supply
2
chain management as well as strategic management by assessing the interplay between important portfolio management capabilities and strategies for dynamically managing supplier portfolios in light of turbulence. This is important, as it will enable managers to focus firm resources better on developing crucial aspects of supplier relationship management capabilities. In summary, managers will this way be able to create a more flexible and agile supply chain in a strategic manner, and thus will not only more efficient but also more effective.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: The effectiveness of a multi-channel marketing approach for relationship management and sales
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
The evolution from a transactional to a relational exchange perspective of marketing is recognized by many authors as an important paradigm shift in marketing (SHETH ET AL., 2002). A relational model was adopted, together with the belief that the long-term relationship processes with customers are more profitable than isolated transactions, and expected to have a positive impact on key indicators such as customer value. Part of this positive impact results from the decreasing costs of serving the customer, increasing customer satisfaction and thus greater willingness to pay higher prices for better services (REINARTZ; KUMAR 2000). To keep customers satisfied in a long-term relationship, it is not sufficient to develop products and services that meet customer needs. Instead, it is also expected that the contacts between customers and businesses take place frequently and through different ways (MENDE; BOLTON; BITNER, 2013). On the one hand these contacts can be are promoted by the clients to obtain information or request additional transactions. On the other, companies also need to establish some form of communication, retention or way of offering new products and services to customers. These contacts take place through marketing channels and relationships established between client corporations (KLAUS; MAKLAN, 2013). Conceptually, the contacts made through multiple marketing channels refer to the practice of providing information, goods and services across two or more channels simultaneously (RANGASWAMY; VAN BRUGGEN, 2005).
Common sense would indicate that the more marketing channels are available between customers and firms, better results can be obtained. Also, contacts could be expected to become more frequent as the firm increasingly adopts multi-channel approach. However, previous research show that this relationship between a higher number of channels or higher number of customer-firm contacts and results is not always positive, and that it can even be in moderated by several factors. For example, Godfrey, Seiders and Voss (2011) found an inverted-U shape that explains the relationships between frequency of usage of specific marketing channels and repurchase. After that optimal point is reached, additional contacts generate "distancing" between the customer and the firm, and the impact on results is increasingly negative. Therefore, increasing the frequency of contacts customer-firm may not always have a positive effect on transactions (THOMAS; SULLIVAN, 2005). However, these authors found that all marketing channels were effective, although presenting an inverted-U shape when it came to impact on revenues. We argue that not all marketing channels are worth having, as that not all channels have a positive impact on customer value.
This aim of this project is to analyze if all marketing channels used by firms to manage its relationships with clients are effective (namely from the synergies that result from their simultaneous usage), and if this effectiveness is moderated by specific factors. Effectiveness is measured in terms of impact different marketing channels have over CLV, or sales and we control for customer segmentation. This project encompasses both B2C and B2B, in four sub-projects and data collection in four different firms and sectors: private pension funds, health and security, IT, and beverages.This research contributes to the growing body of research on the usage of multi-channel strategies by firms to manage relationships with clients. From a managerial perspective, it can help managers allocating resources to push or pull channels, depending no their underlying levels of effectiveness.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Avaliando os impactos das estratйgias de Omnicanalidade no varejo brasileiro
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Na ъltima dйcada, o surgimento de novas tecnologias digitais estreitou os mundos fнsicos e digitais e mudou o comportamento do consumidor que passou a transitar de forma intercambiбvel e simultвnea entre esses dois mundos. Envoltas nesta conjuntura, empresas varejistas foram motivadas a se transformar para o chamado varejo omnichannel, estratйgia que integra os canais e permite aos clientes experiкncia consistente e fluнda entre eles. Uma das estratйgias de omnichannel utilizada й chamada de buy-online-pick-up-in-store, (BOPS) em que o varejista permite que seus clientes comprem no canal online e retirem os produtos nas lojas fнsicas. Contudo, a execuзгo desta estratйgia exige grande esforзo da operaзгo, principalmente das lojas fнsicas. Mas, atй que ponto as lojas fнsicas se beneficiam dessa estratйgia? Este estudo tem como objetivo entender os impactos operacionais e mercadolуgicos da estratйgia BOPS no desempenho das lojas fнsicas.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Sharing economy and collaborative consumption: What drives consumers to participate in new modes of consumptions?
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: The Internet and the Web 2.0 have brought new forms of consumption and changed theconsumer-product relationship. Nowadays, people can include other alternatives of consumption in their decision process beyond the traditional mode of ownership and monetary exchange. Given that the terms sharing and collaborative consumption are new, as they are recent modes of consumption, a misunderstanding of their meaning prevails in the literature and amongst consumers and service providers. The two concepts have been interchangeably used under many nomenclatures, and the differences between them have been frequently overlooked. As a result of being socially desirable (Belk, 2014), the sharing economy concept has rapidly spread out and is often used inappropriately. From a commercial perspective, it became highly beneficial to those who provide services under such banner, despite being, in fact, some form of collaborative consumption. Recent research has identified this problem, and important steps have already been taken to provide a clearer conceptualization for sharing and collaborative based modes of consumption (see for example, Benoit, Baker, Bolton, Gruber, Kandampully, 2017).The aim of this study is twofold: first, by drawing on the existing literature, we establish a clear and comprehensive, yet parsimonious, conceptualization for sharing and collaborative based modes of consumption; second and most importantly, this study evaluates the main reasons why consumers are willing to participate in each mode of consumption, assessing whether there are significant differences in the reasons underlying each of the studied forms of consumption. We draw on the literature review to put forward a conceptual model on the reasons why consumers engage in these two modes of consumption. We use a quantitative approach and structural equation modelling, and test the suggested model.This study makes important theoretical and managerial contributions. From a theoretical perspective, this research provides an overview of the field, as well as a clear conceptualization for each consumption mode. It also provides a more precise understanding of the reasons why participants engage in each form of exchange, and whether there are clear differences between the drivers for each form of consumption. From a managerial perspective, considering that consumer behavior is changing as these forms of exchange are growing all over the world (Bardhi Eckhardt, 2012; Bцcker Meelen, 2017; Hamari et al., 2015), any business can be impacted by this new consumption movement (Botsman Rogers, 2010). Thus, this research helps businesses and managers understand the reasons why participants prefer each of these two types of exchange. The understanding of consumer motivations can allow for the emergence of new business models.The study also provides sharing economy managers with information on how to more effectively differentiate their offer from collaborative forms of exchange, and vice-versa. Managers can thus develop more targeted service offers, as well as more effective communication strategies.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Understanding the effect of bundling on sales performance: A meta-analysis
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Firms widely use bundling sale of two or more products or services in a single transaction as a promotional tactic. Although the use of bundling has grown substantially, there is limited empirical understanding on the association between bundling and performance. A review of accumulated knowledge on the subject is also lacking. This study uses a meta-analysis of 36 published articles on bundling to integrate the effects of bundling strategies and assess their association with performance. The results confirm that, although bundling is associated with reduced customers willingness to pay, due to its promotional nature and inclusion of lower utility products in the bundles, it is also associated with increased sales volume, due to price discounts and added benefits. Furthermore, the association with decreasing willingness to pay is greater in pure bundling and services bundling, and the association with increasing volumes is greater in price bundling, tangible goods, and commodities. The study contributes to theory and practice, providing a theoretical compilation and empirical evidence to support the performance effects of bundling.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Understanding IS' strategic funcion and effectiveness
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: As business-to-business (B2B) sales become digital and multichannel, firms develop inside sales (IS) channels to serve customers and combine such channels with outside sales (OS) and distributor channels in new sales structures. Although IS may offer gains, extant research lacks empirical evidence on their effectiveness in customer value creation when used independently discrete structures and in combination with OS and distributors hybrid structures. This study aims to assess the value creation performance of IS in discrete and hybrid structures. Results from regression estimations of 13,210 B2B customers over two years in a single-firm research design unveil how IS increase value creation when used independently; yet, using IS together with OS or distributors in hybrid structures, decreases performance. IS are more effective in historically less valuable customers and less complex sales processes. This study advances knowledge on multichannel IS structures effectiveness in value creation, helping sales managers allocating resources across channels.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: An International and Dynamic Sudy of Salespeople: A Meta-analysis
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Sales research has long established that salesperson individual and team drivers are key for executing effective selling strategies. Yet radical changes in the sales context in the past decade also require todays salespeople to adapt their selling strategies. Moreover, considering the current international selling environment, many firms pursue a wide range of attractive country markets too, which increases the complexity and challenges of managing country-specific selling strategies. The authors undertake an elasticity meta-analysis of 48 studies, conducted in seven countries and one region (Study 1), to determine the effectiveness of individual and team drivers from a dynamic and global perspective. They also perform a correlation-based meta-analysis of 328 studies conducted in 32 countries (Study 2) to assess the correlations between specific salesperson drivers and performance, and how such correlations might be conditioned by country development and cultural characteristics. The results reveal a positive elasticity of individual and team drivers on performance that decreases over time, providing managers with key empirical insights on sales management; selling skill and aptitude show greater correlation with performance than intrafirm relationship and coordination activity. The country and cultural contingency analysis further indicates a stronger correlation between salesperson drivers and performance outcomes in country markets with high unbranded competition, low resource availability, and high long-term orientation.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: O presente projeto tem como objetivo entender no contexto especнfico de marketplaces, qual o efeito da justiзa interacional percebida durante a recuperaзгo de serviзos na satisfaзгo do cliente com essa recuperaзгo e consequente recompra. Autores apontam que, via uma resoluзгo efetiva por parte da empresa, й possнvel nгo apenas mitigar emoзхes negativas incorridas do problema enfrentado pelo consumidor, mas tambйm instigar a criaзгo de sentimentos positivos, o que interage diretamente na lealdade e satisfaзгo geral percebida pelo cliente. Em razгo da crescente digitalizaзгo e avanзo tecnolуgico, o ambiente digital ganha cada vez mais relevвncia no cotidiano dos brasileiros, que adquirem um nъmero crescente de bens e serviзos via internet. PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: The Interplay Between Cognition, Action and Outcomes:
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
This project is associated with a Special Issue that I am co-editing in the Industrial Marketing Management (A1), an international leading journal in the business-to-business area.
During the last few decades, there has been growing interest in business-to-business studies on cognition and sense-making (IMM Special Issue, Sense-Making and Management in Business Networks, Vol. 39, No. 3). At first, the interest was mainly devoted to examining the relationship between individual cognition and action; later, it became more complex, having evolved towards better understanding how collective cognition emerges in interaction in business networks and what consequences it generates. During this research process, concepts and findings from other disciplines have been adopted and applied to business studies, whilst simultaneously new concepts were developed within this specific area. Among the latter, ?network pictures? or individual subjective interpretations of managers? business context, is one of the most debated and used.
The various research contributions to this area have thus led to a widening of scope in the field. However, this has also resulted in a call for improved clarity and for a stronger integration of parallel research developments from related disciplines. Often concepts from other fields have been applied to the study of business markets, but the integration with existing models of business-to-business marketing has arguably not yet been achieved.
Contributions from other disciplines, such as social and organizational psychology, sociology, business practice studies and strategic management, as well as the application of new methods in the field, are particularly welcome in order to foster a cross-fertilization and multi-disciplinary approach to understanding business-to-business marketing. We welcome both conceptual and empirical papers.
Some, but not exclusive, research questions that we aim to cover with this Special Issue are the following:
. What is the interplay between cognition, managerial action and outcomes within organizations, business relationships and business networks?
. How is this interplay, in business practice, related to formal economic theories, and to market analyses and economic analyses?
. How can the concept of boundary objects help to better understand the way business actors coordinate their actions in interaction in networks?
. How does this interplay affect learning and strategic change in organizations?
. How can research based on the ?network pictures? concept be developed to better understand collective decision-making and interaction in business markets?
. How can Ford et al. (2003)'s model on the interplay between network pictures, networking activities and network outcomes be used and further developed (Ford, D., Gadde, L. E., Hеkansson, H., & Snehota, I., 2003, Managing business relationships. Chichester: John Wiley and Sons)?
. What methods can serve the purpose of empirically addressing the relationship between cognition, action and outcomes?
. How is this relationship affected by ICT (Information and communication technologies) developments?
